Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemistry Function, Application, Structure and Theory (FAST): Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Chemistry and Biochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the REU Sites Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation Professor Stefan A. France recruits undergraduates to participate in a diverse array of projects spanning five interdisciplinary thematic research areas under the programmatic title "Chemistry FAST", or Chemistry Function, Application, Structure, and Theory. In keeping with the nation's interests in creating a highly trained workforce that reflects the growing diversity of the U.S. population, a primary focus of the Georgia Tech FAST Program targets the enrollment of substantial numbers of undergraduate women and students from underrepresented groups to provide them with skills and motivation to embark on careers in the sciences. Undergraduates participate in a diverse array of projects spanning five interdisciplinary thematic research areas. These themes encompass the breadth of research in the chemical sciences that contribute to the well-being (health, wealth, and security) of the nation.

Each participant works with an individual faculty member who has an active research group in a thematic area of interest to the student. The Chemistry FAST Program encompasses five interdisciplinary themes: (i) Biological Systems and Medicinal Application (BSMA); (ii) Catalysis, Energy and Sustainability (CES); (iii) Materials Design and Application (MDA); (iv) Nano- and Quantum- Scale Technologies (NQST); and (v) Sensing, Imaging and Diagnostics (SID). Each theme is specifically grouped to encompass faculty, science and technologies that represent function, application, structure and theory (FAST). Other components of the program include team-building activities, regular group meetings, a seminar/workshop series (ethics, presentation skills, graduate opportunities, and research frontiers), research symposia, and field trips to industrial and/or government laboratories. These activities serve to acquaint participants with a broad array of projects, provide them with the opportunity to enhance their presentation skills, and provide a perspective of chemical research in a scholarly, entrepreneurial, economic, and ethical framework. The program includes extensive joint activities with other summer research programs on campus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the program is to provide a high-quality research experience, augmented by experiential learning components, for a diverse cadre of undergraduate students. The program will provide participants with encouragement and preparation to pursue advanced studies in the sciences while emphasizing the importance of collaboration and interdisciplinarity in chemistry. The FAST Program was developed through careful consideration of how to foster an inclusive environment by making use of formal and informal mentoring, professional development seminars, and excursions highlighting the diversity of careers in science. The Program exposes participants directly to broad realworld problems in energy and sustainability, national and homeland security, health and diagnostics, nanoscience, and quantum computing. This will be accomplished through focused and directed presentations of cutting-edge chemical research in scholarly, entrepreneurial, economic, and ethical frameworks.

The goals of the Research Experience for Undergraduates in Chemistry and Biochemistry at Georgia Institute of Technology are to: (i) engage undergraduate students in research activities in an established and intensive research setting, (ii) involve female and underrepresented minority students in sizable numbers to create a truly diverse cadre of participants, (iii) attract students from schools with limited research activities, (iv) introduce students to the broad community of practicing chemists and various industrial and governmental research organizations in the Atlanta area, and (iv) to encourage talented students to pursue graduate research.

Over the duration of the NSF Award (2016-2019), the CHEM FAST REU Program received 471 total applications, made 75 offers, and had 37 summer participants representing the four summer cohorts. The 37 participants were placed in labs across 19 participating faculty.

The total makeup of the four cohorts was:

Gender:

13/37 (35%) men

24/27 (65%) women

Race/Ethnicity:

15/37 (41%) URM

18/37 (49%) White

12/37 (32%) Black/AfrAm

4/37 (11%) Asian

3/37 (8%) Hispanic

Type of Institution:

13/37 (35%) from colleges

20/37 (54%) from institutions that do not offer PhD in chemistry

5/37 (14%) from Historically Black Colleges and Universities

1/37 (3%) from international partner (through ACS iRES)

Classification:

1/37 (3%) seniors

27/37 (73%) juniors

7/37 (19%) sophomores

2/27 (5%) freshmen

 

Following the REU program and graduation from their home institutions, 20/37 (54%) of participants enrolled in a PhD program at some point. Moreover, 8 students enrolled in Georgia Tech PhD program.
